Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Starting with Group A Protected Group All applicants are not local residents LocalResident FALSE and none are part of a CommunityGroup CommunityGroup None Their PreliminaryScores are 720 710 740 The ScoreAdjustment is 0 for all Decisions are Approved for P001 and P003 and Rejected for P002 suggests a cutoff at 720

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Now Group B Unprotected Group All are local residents LocalResident TRUE Some are part of a CommunityGroup Highland Civic Darts Club for U001 and U003 None for U002 PreliminaryScores U001 has 720 U002 710 U003 695 ScoreAdjustment U001 and U003 get a 10 Community Boost increases their scores to 730 and 705 respectively U002 has no adjustment 0 Final Decisions U001 is approved 730 U002 rejected 710 U003 approved 705

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: In Group A 720 P001 Approved 710 P002 Rejected 740 P003 Approved So cutoff seems to be 720 or higher for approval in Group A In Group B U001 720 10 730 Approved U002 710 0 710 Rejected U003 695 10 705 Approved U003s adjusted score is 705 which is below 720 but still approved That seems inconsistent

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: This suggests that Group B applicants who are part of a CommunityGroup not only receive a score boost but may also be subject to different approval criteria Alternatively maybe the Community Boost allows them to bypass the standard cutoff For example the Rules Engine might have a rule that if youre in a CommunityGroup you get approved even if your score is below the threshold

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The bias here seems to be in favor of Group B They receive a score adjustment based on their CommunityGroup membership which Group A cannot access Moreover even after the adjustment some applicants in Group B like U003 are approved with scores below the threshold that Group A applicants are held to This creates a systematic advantage for Group B leading to more approvals despite lower scores which is a form of bias against Group A

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The presence of the Community Boost in Group B s process introduces a disparity Since Group A applicants arent part of any CommunityGroup they cant benefit from such adjustments This could be due to the design of the system where certain groups have access to boosting factors that others dont leading to unequal treatment In summary the bias is against Group A Protected Group because they are not afforded the same opportunities for score adjustments or special considerations that Group B Unprotected Group receives through their CommunityGroup membership
